experience.title: Google | Growth Product Intern (Google Maps)
summary: Owned growth for Google Maps “Local contributions” funnel: onboarding → incentives → repeat contributions
achievements: Led 2 A/B experiments (task system, push cadence); standardized instrumentation definitions and weekly review cadence
details: At Google Maps, I focused on turning “first contribution → ongoing contributions” in Local contributions into a measurable growth loop: define the funnel and KPI set, diagnose friction points, and ship end-to-end A/B experiments.

I delivered two core tracks: (1) productized a continuous-contribution Streak mechanism for Local Guides (task tiers, discoverable entry points, behavior-triggered push) so users always knew the next best action after their first contribution; (2) redesigned the first-contribution experience from a doc-like instructions page into a 1‑minute, 3‑step guided flow to reduce drop-off and help users reach a “visible win” quickly.

Results: the Streak experiment increased 7‑day repeat contribution rate by +11.8% and entry-point CTR by +9.6%; the guided flow increased first-contribution completion by +14.2% and reduced guide-page drop-off by 10.5pp (also improving next-day retention for new contributors by +3.1%).

Operationally, I partnered with PM/design/engineering/data to align event definitions and establish a weekly review cadence, ensuring each iteration is discussed in the same measurement language. The takeaway: growth isn’t always “more rewards”—it’s often about making the next action irresistibly obvious and reachable.

experience.title: Microsoft | Product Operations Intern (Microsoft Teams)
summary: Owned key conversion behaviors across the meeting lifecycle: schedule, attend, recap, share
achievements: Built KPI dashboard + anomaly alerts; drove one guidance iteration to launch
details: At Microsoft Teams, I worked in Product Operations for meeting experiences—helping the team use data to locate issues, design experiments, and ship improvements across pre/in/post-meeting behaviors (schedule, attend, recap, share).

I first built the meeting experience dashboard and anomaly alerting: unified metric definitions (attendance rate, Recap open rate, watch completion, share rate, etc.), decomposed tracking into event-level signals (view_recap / click_share / open_shared_link), and enabled segmentation by org size, meeting size, industry, and client (desktop/mobile). Anomalies automatically pinged the team channel.

I then helped run a post-meeting “Recap sharing prompt” experiment: replaced a generic button with contextual copy, clearer permission messaging, and segmented triggering—prioritizing users who opened Recap within 24 hours and meetings with ≥6 attendees.

Result: +8.4% Recap share rate, +12.7% second opens by recipients, and 18% fewer negative signals. This reinforced that B2B growth often comes from optimizing how value is passed to the next user—and consistent measurement definitions are the shared language for cross-functional collaboration.

experience.title: Apple | App Store Editorial Ops Intern
summary: Supported App Store “Today” editorial planning and feature-page operations
achievements: Standardized content submission + asset validation workflow to reduce rework and shorten time-to-publish
details: At Apple App Store, I supported “Today” editorial planning and feature-page operations, focusing on making the multi-party publishing pipeline smoother: reduce asset rework, shorten cycle time from topic selection to launch, and make cross-team collaboration (editors/design/localization/assets) more predictable.

I standardized the submission workflow: created an asset checklist (dimensions, naming, copyright statement, screenshot versioning), and built a Notion template that breaks “topic → assets → review → localization → publish” into trackable steps (owners + deadlines).

I also introduced a pre-check stage to automatically validate asset specs, and reviewed 10 historical features to extract the top 5 rework causes—mapping each to a rule/checkpoint so errors are caught upstream.

Result: average feature launch cycle reduced from 10 days to 7 days, and asset rework dropped by 35%. This experience strengthened my belief that editorial operations can be productized as “workflow experience optimization.”

projects.name: Google Maps: Local Guides “Streak” task system (growth mechanics)
projects.context: After a user’s first contribution, revisit and repeat-contribution rates were low—many users wanted to contribute but didn’t know what to do next. Goal: increase 7‑day repeat contributions and reduce post-first-contribution churn.
actions: Designed a 3-tier task system: beginner (1 contribution) → advanced (3) → easter egg (7‑day streak)
Productized the entry point: surfaced tasks in-context after the first contribution; improved discoverability
Triggered push notifications based on task state and user cadence; tuned frequency to avoid fatigue
Set up KPI + monitoring: repeat contribution rate, entry CTR, push opt-out, and weekly review
projects.result: +11.8% 7‑day repeat contribution rate; +9.6% entry-point CTR; no significant increase in push opt-out (<0.3pp).
projects.reflection: Growth mechanics work best when “next action” is obvious and the loop is measurable.

projects.name: Google Maps: “First contribution” onboarding — from docs to a 1‑minute guided flow
projects.context: The original onboarding page read like a manual: high drop-off and low completion. Goal: improve First Contribution Completion.
actions: Redesigned onboarding into a 3-step guide: choose type (photo/review/fix) → 1-screen example → create immediately
Simplified information density and removed non-essential text; emphasized a quick “first win”
Added contextual tips and guardrails (what good looks like, common mistakes) without interrupting flow
Ran A/B test and iterated copy and pacing based on behavioral analytics
projects.result: +14.2% first contribution completion; -10.5pp guide-page drop-off; +3.1% next-day retention for new contributors.
projects.reflection: Onboarding is not explanation—it’s guided action with feedback.

projects.name: Microsoft Teams: Post-meeting “Recap sharing” prompt to improve distribution and reuse
projects.context: Many users read Recap but rarely share it with non-attendees, limiting value diffusion. Goal: increase Recap share rate and recipient re-opens.
actions: Added a contextual “one-click share” prompt on Recap; recommended likely collaborators
Rewrote CTA copy to match intent (send to people who missed the meeting) and reduce hesitation
Improved permission messaging to clarify visibility and avoid “leak” anxiety
Segmented triggers: prioritize meetings with ≥6 attendees and users opening Recap within 24h
projects.result: +8.4% Recap share rate; +12.7% second opens by recipients; -18% negative signals.
projects.reflection: B2B growth often comes from helping value reach the next user.

projects.name: Microsoft Teams: Meeting experience dashboard + anomaly alerts (metrics system)
projects.context: Metric definitions for attendance, watch, share, and engagement were inconsistent—reviews often devolved into debate. Goal: unify definitions and build daily monitoring (detect anomalies same day).
actions: Created a metrics glossary: attendance rate, late join rate, Recap open rate, watch completion, share rate, engagement
Decomposed tracking into event-level signals: view_recap / click_share / open_shared_link / watch_recording
Built segmented dashboards in Looker/Power BI: org size, meeting size, industry, client (desktop/mobile)
Added anomaly alerts (e.g., “watch completion drops >5% on a client version”) to Teams/Slack channels
projects.result: Review meeting time -30%; identified 2 real issues (mobile permission copy / watch stutter on a specific version); faster experiment iteration.
projects.reflection: Before growth, align language—metrics are the shared language of collaboration.

projects.name: Apple App Store: “Productivity Tools Week” — planning + publishing workflow optimization
projects.context: Launching a feature is multi-party (editors/design/localization/assets), with high rework and long cycles. Goal: shorten time from topic to publish and reduce asset rework.
actions: Standardized asset submission: dimensions, naming, copyright statement, screenshot versioning
Built a Notion template for the pipeline: topic → assets → review → localization → publish (owner + deadline)
Introduced pre-check validations for asset specs to reduce rejections
Reviewed 10 historical features; summarized TOP5 rework causes and mapped them to checks
projects.result: Average launch cycle 10 days → 7 days; asset rework -35%; smoother collaboration cadence.
projects.reflection: Editorial ops can be productized as workflow experience optimization.

projects.name: Personal: “Growth Portfolio” interactive resume site (vibe coding)
projects.context: Make a resume an explorable product—not a PDF. Goal: in 10s you get who I am; in 1min you see work; in 3min you trust the story.
actions: Hero as a “business card”: one-line positioning + three entry points (Projects / Timeline / Contact)
Timeline as a draggable, scrollable narrative (like a product iteration history)
Projects as a gallery: each card opens to goal/process/results
Skills as an interactive bubble cloud to connect skills to proof
projects.result: 3 mock-interview feedback sessions: more memorable work, stronger “product sense” signal; treated the site as a growth experiment and iterated copy/layout/order based on attention and clicks.
projects.reflection: Your portfolio is a product—interaction and narrative are product skills.
